description: From Ancient Greek ὁμοιούσιος (homoioúsios), from ὅμοιος (hómoios, “like, similar”) + οὐσίᾱ (ousíā, “essence”).

adjectives.description: homoiousian (comparative more homoiousian, superlative most homoiousian)

entries.meaning: having a similar but not identical essence, especially with reference to the first and second persons of the Trinity
(historical) One of the Semi-Arians of the 4th century who held that the Son was of like, but not the same, essence or substance with the Father.
